description: Borrowed from Latin aura (“a breeze, a breath of air, the air”), from Ancient Greek αὔρα (aúra, “breeze, soft wind”), from ἀήρ (aḗr, “air”). Doublet of east, auster, air, and aria.

nouns.description: aura (plural aurae or auræ or auras)

entries.meaning: Distinctive atmosphere or quality associated with something.
examples: This place has an aura of 19th century Paris.

entries.meaning: (parapsychology) An invisible force surrounding a living creature.
(medicine) Perceptual disturbance experienced by some migraine sufferers before a migraine headache.
(medicine) Telltale sensation experienced by some people with epilepsy before a seizure.
